questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal discomfort. Lab tests show elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). Further testing reveals positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA). A liver biopsy demonstrates interface hepatitis with plasma cell infiltration . Given the specific autoantibody profile and the histological findings, which of the following options is associated with the condition and is most relevant to consider in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type 1 Autoimmune Hepatitis

Type 2 Autoimmune Hepatitis

More common in females (2nd-3rd decade)

More common in children

Associated with:

  • ANA (also seen in SLE) - hence, lupoid hepatitis
  • Anti SMA (Anti smooth muscle antibody) - against actin
  • Anti-soluble liver antigen
  • Atypical p-ANCA (x-ANCA)

Associated with:

  • ANA absent
  • Anti LKM1 (Liver kidney microsome type 1)
  • Anti-liver cytosol - 1 antibody

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, jaundice, abdominal discomfort, and significant weight loss for three months. She reports itchy skin. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA). She has a family history of autoimmune diseases. Which of the following clinical features is most commonly associated with the above scenario?
Which of the following statements regarding Autoimmune Hepatitis is False?

options.label: C
options.text: It is a diagnosis of exclusion

questions.explanation:
Factors supporting diagnosis:

Factors against diagnosis:
  • Female gender.
  • Predominant elevation of aminotransferases.
  • Level of globulin elevation.
  • Presence of other autoimmune diseases.
  • HLA-DR3 or DR4 markers.
  • Positive response to treatment.
  • Predominant elevation of alkaline phosphatase.
  • Presence of mitochondrial antibodies.
  • Positive markers for viral hepatitis.
  • History of hepatotoxic drug use or excessive alcohol consumption.
  • Histological evidence of bile duct injury or atypical features (e.g., fatty infiltration, iron overload).

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary underlying mechanism of injury in Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)?

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic mutation affecting bile acid metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: Viral infection leading to bile duct inflammation

questions.correct_answer: A. Autoimmune-mediated destruction of bile ducts

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with fatigue and pruritus. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase and positive antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

A 40-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and pruritus. He reports a recent onset of jaundice. His past medical history is significant for ulcerative colitis. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin, and atypical pANCA are positive. An MRCP is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

PSC is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of extrahepatic and large intrahepatic bile ducts, with dilation of preserved segments.

Demographics
  • Commonly occurs in individuals aged 30-50 years.
  • Has a male predominance of 2:1.

Pathogenesis
  • Suggests an immunologically mediated process supported by circulating autoantibodies, T lymphocytes in the periductal stroma, and associations with HLA-B8 and ulcerative colitis.
  • A mix of environmental & genetic factors may trigger bile duct injury.
  • Increased risk of PSC in first-degree relatives indicates a genetic component.
  • Activated T cells from ulcerative colitis mucosa may migrate to the liver, targeting bile duct antigens.
  • Changes in the intestinal microbiome or infections may alter cholangiocytes, causing inflammation.
  • Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are

Clinical features
  • Common symptoms include fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice.
  • Nearly 50% of patients are asymptomatic at diagnosis, often identified through elevated serum alkaline phosphatase.
  • Ascending cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis, and chronic cholecystitis may also occur.
  • Fibrosis can progress to cirrhosis over 10-15 years.

Complication

Lifetime risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma is about 20%.

Category

Primary Biliary Cholangitis

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis

Site involved

Intrahepatic

Intrahepatic & Extrahepatic

Gender predominance

Female > male

Male > female

Cause

Autoimmune

Multifactorial (can be autoimmune also)

Clinical features

Fatigue, pruritus, jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • Can be asymptomatic; pruritus, fatigue, abdominal pain, jaundice.
  • Can also develop cholangitis pancreatitis and cholecystitis

Characteristic findings

AMA antibodies are commonly found
  • ERCP/MRCP shows beaded appearance of bile ducts
  • Biopsy shows onion skin fibrosis

Associated conditions

Sjögren's syndrome, autoimmune diseases

Ulcerative colitis, risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with progressive jaundice and pruritus. She has a past medical history of ulcerative colitis. Her LFT revealed an elevated alkaline phosphatase & gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) and a prolonged prothrombin time. The liver biopsy is shown below. Which of the following serologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Workup of Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis

Liver Function Tests

  • Serum ALP is elevated up to 3-4 times.
  • ALT & AST increased.
  • Gamma-glutamyl transferase elevated.
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia (IgM) is elevated.
  • Prothrombin Time is increased.
  • Albumin is reduced.

Serology

P-ANCA +ve in about 65% of patients.

ANA +ve

AMA -ve (Anti mitochondrial antibody)

Imaging
  • MRCP:

Key diagnostic investigation

Reveals (beading) multiple irregular stricturing and dilatations.

  • ERCP:

Reserved for therapeutic intervention

Conducted after MRCP

Liver biopsy

Early features:

  • Periductal "onion skin" fibrosis & inflammation
  • Portal edema & bile ductular proliferation

Later stages show progressive fibrosis leading to biliary cirrhosis and obliterative cholangitis, resulting in "vanishing bile duct syndrome"

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient is treated with a combination of oxycodone and acetaminophen (325 mg per tablet). The patient has a history of opioid tolerance. What is a potential risk associated with this combination?

options.label: C
options.text: Greater likelihood of unintentional acetaminophen overdose.

questions.correct_answer: C. Greater likelihood of unintentional acetaminophen overdose.
questions.explanation:
The Rumack-Matthew nomogram is used to assess the risk of hepatotoxicity by interpreting serum acetaminophen levels in relation to the time since ingestion.

Purpose of the Nomogram:

  • Predicts the risk of hepatotoxicity based on a single acetaminophen concentration at a specific time.
  • Not a prognostic tool; it does not predict fulminant liver failure or death.
  • Best used for acetaminophen concentrations measured 4–24 hours after ingestion.

Lines on the Nomogram:

  • Probable (Rumack-Matthew) Line:
    • Represents the threshold above which 60% of patients are likely to develop hepatotoxicity.
  • Possible (Treatment) Line:
    • Added later by the FDA, incorporating a 25% margin of error for measurement variations or uncertainty about the ingestion time.

Limitations of the Nomogram:

  • Cannot be used for patients presenting more than 24 hours after ingestion or those with multiple ingestions.
  • Less reliable for extended-release acetaminophen or co-ingestion with agents that delay gastric emptying (e.g., anticholinergics, opioids).
  • Safe dose of paracetamol: 3 grams per day
  • Safe dose in the alcoholic patient: 2 grams per day
  • Opioid-PCM combinations are dangerous, as opioid tolerance can lead to increased acetaminophen intake. (Option C)
  • Acetaminophen in opioid combination products is limited to 325 mg per tablet.
  • Toxic Doses:
    • 8 g/day over several days can lead to liver failure.
    • A single dose of 10–15 g may cause liver injury.
    • ≥25 g often results in fatal fulminant liver failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine after taking high doses of acetaminophen for headaches over the past week. Laboratory tests reveal elevated aminotransferases (>10,000 IU/L) and an INR of 2.5. What is the most likely underlying cause of her clinical presentation?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased glutathione levels leading to liver injury

questions.correct_answer: A. Glutathione depletion with NAPQI buildup
questions.explanation:
Metabolism of Acetaminophen
  • Acetaminophen is mainly metabolized via phase II reactions into harmless sulfate and glucuronide metabolites.(Option B)
  • A small portion undergoes phase I metabolism by CYP2E1 (Option D), forming the hepatotoxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI).

Detoxification of NAPQI

  • NAPQI is neutralized by binding to glutathione, forming water-soluble mercapturic acid, which is excreted via the kidneys.

Glutathione Depletion (Option C)

  • When excessive NAPQI is produced, or glutathione is depleted (Option A), NAPQI binds to hepatocyte macromolecules, forming acetaminophen-protein adducts, causing hepatocyte necrosis.

Risk Factors
  • Chronic alcohol use (induces CYP2E1, depletes glutathione).
  • Starvation.
  • Prior use of mixed-function oxidase-inducing drugs (e.g., phenobarbital, INH).
  • Hepatitis C infection increases the risk of liver injury in overdose.

Clinical features

Early Symptoms (4-12 hrs):

  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, shock.

Delayed Symptoms (24-48 hrs):

  • Hepatic injury becomes apparent.
  • Coagulopathy and encephalopathy.
  • Maximal damage seen 3–5 days post-ingestion with aminotransferase levels >10,000 IU/L.
  • Renal failure and myocardial injury may occur.

Stages of acute acetaminophen poisoning

Stage

Time Post-Ingestion

Description

I

0–24 hours

Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.

II

24–72 hours

Right upper quadrant abdominal pain; elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT), and sometimes increased bilirubin and INR if poisoning is severe.

III

72–96 hours

Vomiting, signs of liver failure; peak levels of AST, ALT, bilirubin, and INR. Possible renal failure and pancreatitis.

IV

> 5 days

Recovery of liver function or progression to multiple organ failure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of nausea and abdominal pain after ingesting 20 paracetamol tablets approximately 8 hours ago. His vital signs are stable, but he has mild jaundice. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a liver biopsy to assess damage.

questions.explanation:
Management of Paracetamol poisoning

Management Aspect

Details

Initial Treatment
  • Gastric Lavage
  • Administer activated charcoal or cholestyramine (effective within 30 minutes of ingestion) (Option A)

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) Therapy
  • Initiate within 8 hours of ingestion; may be partially effective up to 24–36 hours post-overdose. (Option B)
  • Administration:
    • IV: 140 mg/kg loading dose over 1 hour, followed by 70 mg/kg every 4 hours for 15–20 doses.

Mechanism of Action
  • NAC acts as a sulfhydryl donor, replenishing glutathione.
  • Neutralizes toxic metabolites and prevents binding to cell proteins, reducing the severity of hepatic necrosis.

Liver Transplantation (Option D)
  • Considered in cases of hepatic failure (jaundice, coagulopathy, confusion).
  • King's College Criteria is used to predict the need for a liver transplant in patients with paracetamol-induced acute liver failure :
  • Arterial blood pH < 7.30

Or all of the following:

  • Prothrombin time (PT) > 100 seconds (INR > 6.5)
  • Serum creatinine > 300 μmol/L
  • Grade III or IV hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents 20 hours after accidentally ingesting a large amount of iron supplements. Initially, she had abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea, but these symptoms have resolved. Her vital signs are stable. What stage of iron toxicity is she experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Phase

Time Frame

Clinical Features

Stage I (Option A)

Gastrointestinal

30 mins to 6 hrs

Primarily gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, hematemesis, and hematochezia.

Stage II (Option B)

Latent

6 to 24 hrs

Apparent recovery phase where GI symptoms may resolve despite significant iron absorption.

Stage III (Option C)

Metabolic Acidosis & Shock

6 to 72 hrs

Recurrence of GI symptoms, shock, metabolic acidosis, and complications like cardiomyopathy, and renal failure.

Stage IV (Option D)

Hepatotoxicity

12 to 96 hrs

Development of acute liver failure.

Coma & coagulopathy.

Stage V

Bowel Obstruction

2 to 8 weeks

Consequences of healing, including scarring and obstruction of the pylorus or proximal bowel.

Management of Iron Toxicity

Treatment Aspect

Details

Activated Charcoal

Ineffective for iron toxicity.

Magnesium Hydroxide
  • 1% oral solution may reduce iron absorption by forming ferrous hydroxide.
  • Therapeutic doses of magnesium hydroxide and calcium carbonate antacids are safe for use.

Laboratory Tests

Obtain serum iron, creatinine, electrolytes, hemoglobin, prothrombin time, liver function tests, and arterial blood gas in severely poisoned patients.

Corrective Measures

Correct hypovolemia and metabolic acidosis.

Chelation Therapy

Agents: Desferrioxamine (IV) or deferiprone (oral).

Indications:

  • Multiple vomiting episodes, significant abdominal pain, hypovolemia, acidosis.
  • Multiple radiopacities on X-ray.
  • Serum iron > 350 mcg/100 ml.

Dosage (Desferrioxamine):

  • IV: Continuous infusion up to 15 mg/kg/hr (up to 35 mg/kg/hr for severe cases in children)
  • Total Daily Dose: Do not exceed 6 grams.
  • Infusion Duration: 8-12 hours for moderate toxicity; > 24 hours for severe toxicity.

Therapy Endpoint
  • Monitor urine for "vin rose" color indicating chelated iron excretion.
  • Therapy can stop when urine color normalizes and the patient is asymptomatic.

Adverse Effects of Desferrioxamine
  • Risk of sepsis (Yersinia enterocolitica, mucormycosis)
  • visual toxicity (low iron stores)
  • ototoxicity (abnormal audiograms),
  • Pulmonary toxicity (high doses)
  • Hypotension (rate-related)
  • Renal toxicity (elevated creatinine).

Additional Treatments
  • Continuous arteriovenous hemofiltration (CAVH) for severe poisoning.
  • Liver transplantation for fulminant hepatic failure.
